Steve Chabot on the line from Cincinnati.

No, I think there are a lot of questions about the health care vote.
I think there's a lot of misunderstanding about what's actually in the health care bill.

But when I go out there, and I talk about the fact that insurance companies will no longer be able to cut you off because of preexisting conditions, when I talk about Congress finally paying for Medicare Part D and making sure that prescription drugs are going to seniors, as was promised by Congress, when I help people understand the rescission policies and the fact that insurance companies can no longer cut you off if you actually get sick and help them understand that in 2014, there will be a very competitive market so that they can go out there and purchase health care that they can't do right now, people tend to be very favorable.
They react unfavorably if it's called a government takeover of health care or, you know, it's a mischaracterization of what's actually in the bill.
But once they understand what's in it, you know, I find that people are very receptive.
Last time around, everybody thought it was a close race.

Why - what do you think has changed?
Well, you know, I think we're going to win again, and, you know, I think the polling, you know, in these races is off.
I think it's often miscounting, certainly, minority voters and younger voters.
So, you know, certainly, the atmosphere has changed.

In January of 2009, we lost 750,000 jobs in that month alone.
The economy was in freefall.

We've seen GDP growth in the last four quarters.
We've seen the market go from 6,400 - I believe it was, in March of 2009 to now - over 11,000.

It can't be quick enough for somebody that's unemployed.
It can't be quick enough or - you know, for somebody that's looking for a job and can't find it.
But I think things are pointing in the right direction.
